Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Mantle Rheology and the Dynamics of Suboceanic Mantle: A Bottom-Up Approach
Award.AbstractNarration: The pattern of flow in the mantle cannot be observed directly but is informed by implementing models of known physical behavior of Earth materials in computer simulations. There are uncertainties associated with this approach and this project targets one of them- the imperfect knowledge about how mantle minerals deform. Laboratory studies provide constraints but both the direct measurements and the inferred material flow laws have uncertainty. A quantitative description of this uncertainty in microscopic behavior will, for the first time, be included directly in the macro-scale mantle flow simulations. This will result in a probabilistic description of the model spaces relevant for the Earth for a range of likely constituent architectures. Local mineral deformation mechanism, grain size, potential temperature, pressure, water, and melt are all known to affect stress-strain relations in mantle rock. A previously developed Bayesian method will be modified to allow various architectures to be included. A graduate student will receive training at a forefront of numerical modeling in geophysics and will gain insight to laboratory results- a cross disciplinary background that is not typical in most departments. A website will be developed for researchers to query for self-consistent descriptions of mantle flow law specification.

ProgramReference.Text: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

POR.DRECONTENT:
Almost all kinds of geological activities on the Earth are ultimately driven by mantle convection, which is the subsurface currents of solid rocks acting over billions of years. Our understanding of how mantle rocks deform is, however, still very limited because rock deformation depends on many factors such as temperature, pressure, stress, and chemical composition. The only way to reveal such a complex functionality of rock deformation (called a flow law) is through conducting deformation experiments in the laboratory, but because laboratory deformation is conducted under conditions very different from natural settings, the application of laboratory-based findings to the Earth requires considerable extrapolations, thereby requiring us to carefully analyze experimental data and fully quantify relevant uncertainties. A rigorous statistical approach, first proposed in 2008 by the PI, has been further elaborated and expanded to implement a versatile inversion code, with which we are now able to analyze a variety of experimental data in a unifying fashion. We can estimate a flow law with its uncertainty fully quantified, and this will be important for future studies on mantle dynamics, for which a solid understanding of rock mechanics has become more important ever.

In this project, using a newly implemented inversion code, we have reanalyzed classic experimental data on both olivine single crystals and olivine aggregates. Whereas the former reanalysis was able to successfully reproduce most of the previous results, the latter yielded surprising outcomes: most of original results cannot be reproduced. This is of critical importance, because the deformation of olivine aggregates is what is usually considered to govern the dynamics of the Earth’s upper mantle, and the flow laws estimated from these classic studies have been foundational to our understanding of mantle dynamics for many years. We have found that our understanding of rock mechanics is much more uncertain than commonly believed, but at the same time, we are also able to find a novel way to use our inversion code to help future experimental efforts in the most effective manner. We believe that the outcomes of this project mark an important first step toward truly productive collaborations between rock mechanics and mantle dynamics in future.
